input: Write a short biography of Bill Nye.
output: William Milliken Nye (born 1955) is a U.S. actor, comedian, scientist, and activist. He is best known for his PBS children's show "Bill Nye the Science Guy," for which he earned 18 Emmy award nominations. Nye was born in DC, studied aeronautics at Columbia, and taught science at Cornell before writing "Everything: How Physics Makes Everything Interesting" (2017). A popular speaker, Nye was recently named the CEO of the Planetary Society to focus on space exploration and climate change.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100-44 BCE) was Rome's first Emperor and one of the world's most celebrated political figures. A lifelong soldier, Julius Caesar overthrew the Roman Republic and gained political power, eventually establishing a constitutional monarchy. He expanded the Roman Empire and modernized the political system. Though his rule was often repressive and extravagant, Julius Caesar wrote some of the most admired works in Latin literature and laid the foundation for the rule of the Roman Empire.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100-44 BCE) was a Roman statesman and general who became dictator and led campaigns in Britain, Gaul, and Alexandria to make Rome the dominant power in the Mediterranean. The nephew of a military tribune, Caesar worked his way up the ranks, entering politics as an orator around 85 BCE. Elected to the praetorship of Rome’s most prestigious post in 63 BCE, he served the most important roles in the senate, winning victories in the Gallic Wars and later as general and consul. While he became dictator and consul over the coming decades, the assassination of Caesar by Brutus and other leading politicians ended Caesar’s life and began the Roman Civil War.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100 BC-44 BC) was a Roman general and statesman who conquered much of the known world. Leaving a modest military career, he led a civil war against his rivals, winning a series of crushing victories during the Roman Civil War. Taking power in an uprising in 49 BC, Caesar ruled the Rome as a dictator until he was assassinated in 44 BC. He remade the Roman Republic into the Roman Empire, creating a powerful central authority in the city of Rome. He conquered territories throughout Europe, the Mediterranean, and the Near East, establishing new provinces and annexing foreign territories.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (100-44 B.C.E.) was a Roman general and political leader. A skilled general, he helped subdue foreign foes and reform the Roman Republic. He came to oppose this political system's oligarchic structure and rose to power, killing the dictator Lucius Cornelius Sulla. Caesar led as dictator, transforming the Republic into an empire. He fought a civil war with the aristocratic party, ultimately defeating them. But he fell to violence, as assassins stabbed him at the Senate. Caesar's leadership shaped Rome into a powerful empire.

input: Write a short biography of Julius Caesar.
output: Julius Caesar (ca 100 BCE-44 BCE) was a Roman soldier, general, and statesman. One of Rome's greatest military leaders, he conquered a half of the known world, including parts of North Africa and the Middle East. Caesar held the consulship in 59 BCE and was then called upon by the Roman Senate to end a war with the tribes of Gaul. Caesar defeated the Gauls, establishing himself as Rome's leading general. He reorganized the legions, expanded his support, and established a senatorial dictatorship. With the support of the Senate and his soldiers, he went on to invade Egypt, the richest country in the world. He made it as far as Alexandria, but died in 44 BCE under suspicious circumstances. After the death of Caesar, the factions of the Roman Republic fought for control, which eventually led to the rise of Emperor Augustus. Historians continue to debate Caesar's motives and legacy, but his success set in motion key developments in Roman and European history.

input: Write a short biography of Dian Fossey.
output: Dian Fossey (born 1932) was born in San Francisco and became renowned for leading a team of scientists investigating mountain gorilla populations in the Virungas. Fossey trained in zoology and biology and worked at several zoos before founding the Karisoke Research Center in Rwanda. She became increasingly interested in conservation during her work with the gorillas. The Dian Fossey Gorilla Fund continues her work in Rwanda and advocates for primate conservation.

input: Write a short biography of Dian Fossey.
output: Dian Fossey (1932-1985) led the scientific research of mountain gorillas. Fossey studied the primate group of Rwanda's Virunga Mountains where she built Camp Karisoke in 1963. Her observations laid the groundwork for conservation of mountain gorillas. She established the Karisoke Research Center and Gorilla Doctors nonprofit to help endangered wildlife. During the 1966 Rwandan Revolution, Fossey was attacked by poachers, and later accused them of murder. Her body was found in 1985. Fossey's life and work inspired the 1988 film "Gorillas in the Mist," the 1985 book "Gorillas in the Mist," the documentary film "King of the Mountain," and the novel "Night Song."

input: Write a short biography of The Rolling Stones.
output: The Rolling Stones were an English rock band formed in 1962. The original lineup consisted of Mick Jagger (lead vocals), Brian Jones (lead guitar), Keith Richards (rhythm guitar), Mick Taylor (guitar), Bill Wyman (bass guitar), Peter (Charlie) Watts (drums) and Ian Stewart (keyboards). After Watts’s departure in 1974, Wyman also left the same year and the band carried on. The band is widely regarded as one of the most iconic rock and roll bands in history. They've had over 20 members, recorded over 30 albums, and sold an estimate at 250 million records. They were inducted to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1989 and honored with the Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award and Brit Awards, amongst other honors.

output: The Rolling Stones are an English rock band formed in London in 1962. As part of the so-called British Invasion, they were one of the most important groups in rock music throughout the 1960s. They were one of the first groups of the rock genre to emerge in the UK, along with competitors The Beatles, The Who, and Kinks. input: Write a short biography of Jane Goodall.
output: Jane Goodall (born 1934) is a British primatologist and anthropologist. She first came to the attention of the British public in 1964, when she embarked on a visit to the little known Gombe Stream National Park in Tanzania. There she began a scientific study of the social and family interactions of wild chimpanzees. The Gombe Project, as she calls it, continues to this day and is now a part of the World Wildlife Foundation. Goodall and the 14-year-old chimpanzee named David Greybeard made headlines worldwide. Following the Gombe Project, the now respected scientist founded the Jane Goodall Institute, whose goal is to help "redefine the relationship between people and animals and develop ways in which both can live in mutual respect."

input: Write a short biography of Jane Goodall.
output: Jane Goodall (born 1934) is the founder of numerous nature centers devoted to chimpanzees. She is best known as the leading expert on primates and behavior and a pioneer of the modern animal rights movement. Goodall began her research in 1960 in Tanzania, studying chimpanzees in a natural setting. Her work with these chimpanzees, in turn, helped re-shape the scientific understanding of primate psychology and behavior, including language. Goodall's legacy includes establishing 10 sanctuaries throughout Africa and teaching thousands of young students about animal conservation. In 2020, she became a UN Messenger of Peace.

input: Write a short biography of Oprah Winfrey.
output: Oprah Gail Winfrey (born 1954) is an American media mogul, actress, producer, and philanthropist. As a television host and talk show, she has hosted her eponymous show, "The Oprah Winfrey Show," since 1984. Winfrey's success led to production and distribution of films and TV shows for her network, OWN, and her production company, Harpo Productions. She has won awards including an Emmy, Oscar, Tony, Grammy and National Film Registry selection. She was the first African American woman to win an Academy Award and the first black women to direct a film nominated for an Academy Award. After leaving "The Oprah Winfrey Show," Winfrey returned to acting. Her role in the film "Lee Daniels' The Butler" was critically acclaimed and she has appeared in multiple films since. She earned a Best Supporting Actress nomination for her role in the HBO limited series "The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks" and has served as executive producer on multiple television shows and films.

input: Write a short biography of Cleopatra.
output: Greek ruler Ptolemy XII proclaimed that his wife, Cleopatra, was his sister in order to give himself authority and keep her from overthrowing him. Cleopatra, however, had a different father, Ptolemy I, and was the daughter of Philip II and Cleopatra V of Macedon. She and her brother and co-ruler, Ptolemy XIII, ascended the throne of Egypt in 51 BCE after the death of their father. Despite her efforts, Ptolemy's army defeated Ptolemy's, ending her rule. Cleopatra is best known for her affair with Julius Caesar, giving birth to their son, Caesarion, and for having the Roman leader assassinated. She also had an affair with Mark Antony, leading to their son, Alexander Helios. When Mark Antony committed suicide, she fled to Egypt. There, she received a pugil stick from her servant and killed herself, rather than live humiliated as a captive of Octavian, the Roman general and Cleopatra's one time lover.

input: Write a short biography of Cleopatra.
output: Cleopatra VII (c.69–30 BCE) was the last queen of the Ptolemaic Kingdom of Egypt before Egypt became part of the Roman Empire. Following the assassination of her father Ptolemy XII, she and her siblings were raised in Rome by Mark Antony and his sister Octavia. When Antony appointed himself governor of Egypt in 41 BCE, she returned to the country and formed a personal, romantic relationship with the Roman leader. The couple ruled jointly, and when Antony died in 30 BCE, she returned to Rome and married her young son with Antony to Octavian's sister Octavia. When Cleopatra committed suicide by snakebite in 30 BCE, Octavian installed Ptolemy XIV sole ruler of Egypt.

output: Cleopatra VII Philopator (69 BC-July 11 or August 12, 30 BC) was the last Greek ruler of Egypt. She assumed the throne in 51 BC around the same time as Julius Caesar died. She initially sought alliances with both Caesar and Marc Antony, but married Antony and bore a son. As they fell out, Cleopatra sided with Caesar's rival, Octavian. She and Mark Antony both committed suicide following the Battle of Actium. Cleopatra's reign in Egypt, which ended in 30 BC, included a shift to a powerful monarchy. She is depicted in history and pop culture to this day.

output: Cleopatra VII (69-30 B.C.E.) was the last pharaoh of the Ptolemaic kingdom. Her political maneuver with Julius Caesar and Marc Antony, though ultimately unsuccessful, won her a place as one of the most celebrated figures in history. Cleopatra's life and historical importance have been a point of debate for scholars and have resulted in a variety of histories and films. Some have argued for her involvement in the assassination of Julius Caesar and in the military campaigns of her husband, Marc Antony. Others emphasize her influence on Caesar and the formation of his legacy. output: Cleopatra (69-30 BC) was a famed queen of the Ptolemaic dynasty who reigned in Egypt from 66 BC to 48 BC. Already a famous beauty of her day, she soon became the lover of Roman leader Julius Caesar. She succeeded Caesar as ruler with the support of ruler Rome and was an important figure in Caesar's civil war. She later became involved in a power struggle with her brother and Roman general Anthony. This resulted in his defection to the side of another Roman leader, Octavian, who later became the emperor Augustus.

input: Write a short biography of Cleopatra.
output: Cleopatra (69BC-30BC) was the last pharaoh of ancient Egypt. The daughter of Ptolemy XII, Cleopatra is perhaps the world's best-known female ruler. In 48 BC, Egypt became a protectorate of Rome. Her rule was marked by diplomacy and the use of political marriages to preserve her dynasty. She and her rival Julius Caesar had three children together, while her son and Caesar's adopted heir, Caesarion, died in 30 BC at the hands of the Romans. Her brother Ptolemy XIV was killed and she committed suicide. Cleopatra was the subject of several novels and films, including the 1963 classic starring Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton.

input: Write a short biography of The Weeknd.
output: Abel Makkonen Tesfaye (1990) is a Canadian singer, songwriter, and record producer known by the stage name The Weeknd. Born in Toronto to Ethiopian and Eritrean parents, he began his musical career by posting songs on YouTube anonymously in 2010. His debut mixtape in 2010 was followed by Echoes of Silence in 2011, and his first major-label mixtape in 2012, Thursday. In 2012, he released Echoes of Silenx Volume 2 and recorded his second major-label mixtape, Trilogy. His debut studio album, Kiss Land, was also released in 2013. Three studio albums have followed: Beauty Behind the Madness (2015), Starboy (2016), and My Dear Melancholy (2019). The Weeknd has won Grammy Awards and been nominated for an Academy Award and multiple Juno Awards.

Before breaking onto the big screen, Elba made his name on British TV shows like The Bill and The Office. His critically-acclaimed roles have landed him a Golden Globe nomination. He was named GQ's "Man of the Year" in 2018. In addition to acting, he has released three studio albums as DJ Big Driis and founded the musical collective The Noise Makers. He is a UN Goodwill Ambassador for the Sustainable Development Goals.

input: Write a short biography of Aretha Franklin.
output: Aretha Franklin (1942-2018) was an African-American soul and blues singer, songwriter and musician. At age 14, Aretha began singing in her father's church choir. She released her debut album, Aretha Winslow, while in high school and was discovered by Atlantic Records. Franklin's signature style drew on elements of gospel and blues and was an influential force in the development of soul and R&B as a distinct form. During her career, she won 18 Grammy Awards and was the first woman to be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame, as well as one of the only two women there at the time. She was also the third artist, after Elvis Presley and the Beatles, to be awarded the Pulitzer Prize. Franklin's signature song, "Respect," became a huge hit in 1967 and has often been hailed as an anthem of women's empowerment.

input: Write a short biography of Aretha Franklin.
output: Aretha Franklin (1942-2018) was an American singer, songwriter, and pianist. Known as the Queen of Soul, she influenced generations of musicians. Franklin found success in the 1960s, topping the Billboard R&B chart with songs like "Do Right Woman, Do Right Man" (1966) and "I Say a Little Prayer" (1968). She broke into the American mainstream with the disco hit "I Knew You Were Waiting for Me" (1987), and was named the world's most successful female singer of all time. Franklin was active for over six decades and won sixteen Grammy Awards. In 2016, Franklin became the youngest person to be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.

Aretha Franklin was awarded the Nation of Islam Medal of Valor in 1996.

input: Write a short biography of Aretha Franklin.
output: Aretha Franklin (1942-2018) was an American singer, pianist, and songwriter. Often referred to as the "Queen of Soul," Franklin combined gospel, blues, pop, jazz, and traditional roots styles in her music. She began performing at the age of 14, first in church, and then at her father's Baptist church in Detroit where many of the city's renowned musicians performed. Signing with Columbia Records in 1956, Franklin released her first album in 1960, following it with her first charting single, "Rock-A-Bye-Baby" in 1956. Franklin had a number of hits in the late 1960s, like "Respect," "Baby I Love You," and "Spanish Harlem," cementing her status as a major star. She died of pancreatic cancer in August 2018.

input: Write a short biography of Aretha Franklin.
output: Aretha Franklin (1942-2018) was a Grammy-winning American singer, pianist, and civil rights activist. She gained fame with hits such as "Respect," "Baby I Love You," "Chain of Fools," "Do Right Woman-Do Right Man," and "Think." She began singing at the age of five and released her first gospel album in 1956. At the age of 19, she signed with Columbia Records and recorded her first secular single. At 22, she signed with Atlantic Records, beginning a three-decade long relationship with the label. On stage, she earned a reputation as a powerful soul singer, with R&B, blues, jazz, and gospel influences. Franklin also pursued an acting career, appearing in television and film. She earned multiple Grammy awards and performed at the White House. Franklin supported civil rights activism, and in 1997, President Clinton honored her with the National Medal of Arts and the Presidential Medal of Freedom. Franklin was a leading voice in the US women's movement and was nominated for an Academy Award, Emmy, and Tony.

input: Write a short biography of Wangari Maathai.
output: Wangari Maathai (1940-2011) was the first African woman to win the Nobel Peace Prize and one of the key figures of Kenya's unarmed struggle against successive dictatorial regimes. Born in Nyeri, she trained as a veterinary surgeon and worked at the University of Nairobi. Maathai founded the Green Belt Movement in 1977, focusing on environmental protection, women's empowerment, and democratic reform. When the current President Daniel arap Moi was elected in 1978, Maathai's civil society initiatives became a threat to the government. In the 1990s, she campaigned against land grabbing and became an outspoken opponent of corruption. She won the Nobel Peace Prize, Kenya's first ever female Prime Minister, Julia Ojiambo, was elected in 2018.

output: Bette Davis (1908-1989) was an American actress, a six-time Academy Award-winning star of film. A vibrant personality and one of Hollywood's most successful women, Davis was nicknamed The First Lady of Paramount Pictures. Davis appeared in 152 films between 1930 and 1989, with 58 of those earning her a Best Actress nomination. For her portrayal of Margo Channing in the 1950 film All About Eve, she earned her first Oscar. It followed with Best Actress nominations for Dark Victory (1939) and Jezebel (1939). Other films include Now, Voyager (1942), Death on the Nile (1978), All the King's Men (1949), and Whatever Happened to Baby Jane? (1962).

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Kahneman.
output: Daniel Kahneman (born 1934) is a German-born psychologist who won a share of the 2002 Nobel Prize in economics for his studies of how people make decisions. Moving to the United States in 1964, he became a professor of psychology and public affairs at Princeton and, after retiring in 1996, continued to conduct research at the university. Kahneman's 2011 book "Thinking, Fast and Slow" is now required reading for most introductory psychology courses. The book describes the work between fast and slow thinking, our biases, and the many illusions that affect our decision-making. The Economist magazine has described Kahneman as "arguably the most influential psychologist of the second half of the 20th century."

input: Write a short biography of Daniel Kahneman.
output: Daniel Kahneman (1934-2019) was a Nobel Prize-winning psychologist and behavioral economist. He spent more than four decades working at Princeton University while cofounding the field of behavioral economics. His first career goal was to advance psychological theory through experimental methods, but that changed when he met Amos Tversky while attending Hebrew University in Israel. With Tversky, Kahneman proposed the notion of "system one" and system two thinking, which won him the Nobel Prize in 2002. He passed away in 2019 at the age of 85.

input: Write a short biography of Mark Twain.
output: Samuel Langhorne Clemens (1835-1910), better known by his pseudonym Mark Twain, is one of America's most revered authors. Clemens worked as a printer's apprentice as a young man, moving to the Mississippi River and then California during the Gold Rush. He traveled to the Sandwich Islands (now Hawaii) and Europe before publishing his first novel, The Celebrated Jumping Frog of Calaveras County, in 1865. He published a series of satires, most notably The Adventures of Tom Sawyer, in 1876. His life and work are celebrated for their humor, adventure, and critical commentary.

input: Write a short biography of Rosa Parks.
output: Rosa Parks (1913-2005) was a civil rights and labor rights activist. She gained worldwide fame when she refused to give up her seat on a racially segregated bus in Montgomery, Alabama in 1955. input: Write a short biography of Anne Frank.
output: Anna (Anne) Frank (1929-1945) was a young Jewish girl whose wartime diary chronicles her experiences hiding from the Nazis in Amsterdam. Born in Germany, Frank moved to Amsterdam in 1933 with her family. After the Gestapo captured the family's hiding place in 1944, Frank and family were deported and died in the Auschwitz-Birkenau death camp. input: Write a short biography of Anne Frank.
output: Anne Frank (1929-1945) was a German-born Jewish victim of the Holocaust. Writing in her diary, her most cherished possession, she left us an extraordinary account of how life was in Nazi-occupied Amsterdam during World War II. Following raids by the Nazi SS, Anne and her family hid in secret rooms at the back of her father's office. This became Anne's famous "Secret Annexe." In 1944, they were sent to Auschwitz-Birkenau, then Bergen-Belsen, where in 1945 she died from typhus. Anne's father published her diary after the war, and it became a bestseller, translated into more than 60 languages. Anne was later honored as the "diary of an Anne" and later turned into major films.

input: Write a short biography of Cary Grant.
output: Cary Grant (1904-1986) was a British film actor known for his good looks and charm. He grew up in Bristol before working as a bank clerk's assistant and beginning an acting career. His portrayal of a struggling actor in British silent cinema earned him the name "Gary Grant," leading to the famous alias. In Hollywood, Grant specialized in romantic comedies and romantic thrillers. He worked extensively with screenwriter and director George Cukor, garnering four Oscar nominations. Grant was a prominent member of the Hollywood elite before retiring in 1966. For the rest of his life, he spoke out about the problems he saw in film acting, stating that actors were "pantomimes who mug for the camera."

input: Write a short biography of Cary Grant.
output: Cary Grant (1904-1986) was a British-American actor and Hollywood legend. He moved to the United States as a young man and began to study acting. Grant joined Paramount in 1932, playing romantic leads with his suave personality. His career faltered in the 1930s, but it was not long until Grant was the biggest star in Hollywood. He was one of the first actors to get a $1 million salary on a movie, later earning $500,000 per picture. Grant starred in the classic screwball comedy "His Girl Friday" and a string of memorable films, including "Rope," "To Catch a Thief," "North by Northwest," "An Affair to Remember," and "The Philadelphia Story." In 1987, Grant was posthumously inducted into the American Film Institute's list of the top 100 movie stars of all time.

output: Audre Lorde (1934-1992) was an American writer and prominent civil rights activist. She rose to prominence in the 1960s and 70s, her work focused on Black women's empowerment. Lorde came out as lesbian in her teens and married Tynnetta Crosby in 1962, divorcing in 1970. Her first poetry collections, The First Cities (1968) and Cables to Rage (1970), were well-received. input: Write a short biography of Neil Armstrong.

Armstrong joined the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics' predecessor in 1955 and later NASA's astronaut corps. input: Write a short biography of Neil Armstrong.
output: Neil Armstrong (1930-2012) was the first person to walk on the Moon as part of the Apollo 11 mission on July 21, 1969. The son of a veteran of World War I, Armstrong studied aeronautical engineering and served in the Navy Corp. He joined the National Advisory Committee for Aeronautics, where he worked under Wernher von Braun who helped Nazi Germany build the V-2 rocket. In 1962, he became the first civilian to fly in space. He co-piloted the Gemini 8 mission with David Scott in 1966 and commanded the Gemini XI mission in 1966. Armstrong was the commander of Apollo 11, piloting the lunar module to the Moon. He said the first words from the Moon: "That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind."

input: Write a short biography of Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie.
output: Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie (born 1977) is an award-winning Nigerian novelist and short story writer. Adichie grew up in eastern Nigeria before studying abroad at the University of Port Harcourt and Yale University. input: Write a short biography of Indira Gandhi.
output: Indira Priyadarshini (1917-1984) was the fourth Prime Minister of India, winning power in a military coup in 1966. During her 17 years in office, Gandhi expanded Indian hegemony over South Asia. She nationalized numerous industries and supported rural development programs while opposing the spread of Marxism from India's neighbors. Gandhi became preoccupied with political security after Pakistan invaded in 1971. She responded with Operation Blue Star, which saw the army arrest her political rivals and destroy a Sikh temple. Gandhi became an authoritarian ruler, imposing censorship and suspending civil liberties. She died after being shot by two Sikh bodyguards in 1984. Her son, Rajiv, succeeded her as Prime Minister.

input: Write a short biography of Indira Gandhi.

Daughter of Jawaharlal Nehru, she helped to lead India through tumultuous decades of independence and independence, promoting national development while expanding her already strong authoritarian streak as a leader. She helped India overcome the traumatic violence of the Partition period, shepparded the nation through the Emergency period and her government created the Green Revolution. She also initiated an ill-judged war in 1965 with Pakistan, which she eventually lost when the Indians suffered a humiliating defeat at the battlefield. After losing her government in 1977, Gandhi took office again in 1980. She was murdered in 1984 during a disastrous, though controversial campaign. She is revered nationally as a great heroic leader.

input: Write a short biography of Indira Gandhi.
output: Indira Gandhi (1917-1984) was an Indian politician who served three terms as Prime Minister of India from 1966-1977 and 1980-1984. One of her most notable accomplishments was authorizing the 1976 war with Pakistan. While pursuing social reform policies of her father, Indian independence hero Jawaharlal Nehru, she authorized the Indian invasion of the Sikkim region, which later received international recognition by the border treaty. She resumed a Nehruvian approach after the invasion and increased government spending and control over the Indian state-run economy. Gandhi also suspended the constitution, authorized surveillance of citizens, and imprisoned political opponents. Alongside her father, she was voted the most influential person of the 20th century in India.

input: Write a short biography of Indira Gandhi.
output: Indira Nehru Gandhi (1917-1984) was the fourth Prime Minister of India. A powerful Nehru supporter, she helped establish Indian democracy after independence and served as India's leader from 1964-1977. Her nationalistic economic policies were disavowed by Congress when it returned to power. Gandhi was elected Prime Minister again in 1980 and launched a campaign against militant groups in Punjab and Sindh. She was assassinated in 1984, leading to the 1984 Anti-Sikh Riots and her bodyguards' conviction. She was the only leader to continue in office for a third consecutive term, and historians often rank her among India's most prolific Prime Ministers.

input: Write a short biography of Indira Gandhi.
output: Indira Gandhi (1917-1984) became Prime Minister after her father was assassinated in 1969. At age 50, she was the nation's youngest premier. Gandhi ruled the country for much of the next three decades. She began her government by consolidating her party's power, moving to liberalize the economy, and curtailing a Muslim insurgency. She suspended civil liberties in the late 1970s, leading to the emergency. Gandhi restored civil rights after declaring a formal victory against Pakistan in 1975, but the government faced severe criticism over its conduct. She was killed by two of her own bodyguards.

input: Write a short biography of Indira Gandhi.
output: Indira Gandhi (1917-1984) was an Indian socialist leader who served as prime minister from 1966-77, 1980-84. Gandhi was the daughter of Jawaharlal Nehru, the early architect of India's anti-colonial movement, and wife of prime minister Feroze Gandhi. She joined the Congress Party in the late 1940s. Gandhi was seen as a "people's leader," gaining popularity for her efforts to redistribute wealth and feed the thousands of hungry following a failed 1965 war with Pakistan. She established the socialist state-run "Gandhi Development Corporation" in 1973. The state's economic collapse during the 1974-76 famine led to riots against her, including the Emergency, a period of limited civil liberties. The government's repression of the opposition and Gandhi's personal corruption led to her downfall, which culminated in her assassination by her bodyguards in 1984.

input: Write a short biography of Indira Gandhi.
output: Indira Gandhi (1917-1984) was an Indian politician, born and raised in Delhi. She worked as her father's secretary before becoming an active member of the independence movement. Indira Gandhi became Prime Minister in 1966 and took control of the party in 1971. She launched several state-sponsored development programs, the most influential being the Green Revolution of the 1970s. Her government adopted a centrist, pro-market stance and also sought rapprochement with China. In 1976, Gandhi proclaimed herself as Prime Minister indefinitely, triggering a constitutional crisis. After losing support, she resigned in 1977 and was reelected in 1980. After a long political rift between the central government and the state governments of several parties, Gandhi's government declared a state of emergency in 1975. A prominent political figure for most of her life, Indira Gandhi was assassinated in 1984.

Originally elected in 1966, Gandhi faced opposition in 1975 from Congress members following the arrest of her political opponent, and in 1977, she lost to the Janata Party. Reelected in 1980, Gandhi became one of the world's most powerful and powerful female leaders of all time. She successfully negotiated the 1971 Bangladesh Accords. Her party lost major seats in the 1984 elections when she announced a unilateral nuclear weapons test. She was assassinated in 1984.

output: Amelia Earhart (1897-1937) was an American aviation record-setter, writer, and activist. The first woman to earn an airline transport pilot license, Earhart became an early advocate for women's rights. Traveling the United States and Europe, she spoke at high-profile venues and met presidents. In 1937, Earhart began a round-the-world flight in an attempt to set a new record. input: Write a short biography of Tina Turner.
output: Tina Turner (born 1939) is an American record producer, singer and actress. She released her first single as Tina Turner when she was eleven, then joined Ike Turner's Ike Turner and Kings of Rhythm by 1960. Beginning in the 1960s, they released several singles and formed a successful musical partnership. In the 1970s, Turner was a solo artist with Rufus & the Pulsations, the Ike and Tina Turner Revue, and Hot Love Machine. In 1976, Turner's solo album Tina Turner charted in the US and UK, and in 1978 with the RnR album, which reached No. 1 in the UK. Her singles and albums have won three GRAMMY Awards, one Academy Award, four American Music Awards, and seven World Music Awards. A recipient of the Kennedy Center Honors in 2018, Turner is the highest-earning female musician in the world.

input: Write a short biography of Tina Turner.
output: Anna Mae Bullock (1939-2020), better known as Tina Turner, was an American singer, dancer, and actress. She began performing with her then-husband, Ike Turner, at the age of 18. Their successful marriage-turned-estrangement later inspired the 1993 biopic Ike & Tina Turner: On Our Way to Heaven. After becoming a major R&B artist with the 1971 song "River Deep -- Mountain High," her career took off with 1974's "What's Love Got to Do With It?" She has continued a solo career to the present day, becoming a worldwide star with albums like Private Dancer (1984), Break Every Rule (1986), the Tina Turner soundtrack (1993), and Twenty Four Seven (1999). Turner has been inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame and Rock and Roll Museum of Fame. By 2018, she had sold more than 200 million recordings worldwide.

input: Write a short biography of Rosa Luxemburg.
output: Rosa Luxemburg (1870-1919) was a Polish-born revolutionary who promoted international socialism. While a student she joined the movement for Polish independence, and was imprisoned by the Russians for her activism. Luxemburg founded the German Social Democrat Party in 1901. She was a prolific writer and journalist, authoring _The Accumulation of Capital_ and _The Workers' Course._ She co-founded the Spartacus League in 1914. During World War I she worked to undermine Germany's war effort through mass strikes and organized labour. After Germany's 1918 defeat, Luxemburg was killed by right-wing soldiers. She is remembered as a heroic defender of democracy and the worker class.

input: Write a short biography of Rosa Luxemburg.
output: Rosa Luxemburg (1870-1919) was a revolutionary philosopher and activist. Originally working as an educator in Polish territories, she became involved with left-wing Marxist circles. Luxemburg's socialist ideas drew on the Hegelian ideal of history as progress. Concepts of reform and struggle informed her writings, which criticized both capitalism and "bourgeois" socialism. In opposition to her main rival, Vladimir Lenin, she advocated non-violence and cooperation. Assassinated in 1919, Luxemburg is remembered as a key pioneer of the European radical left.

input: Write a short biography of Rosa Luxemburg.
output: Rosa Luxemburg (1870-1919) was a Polish-born revolutionary socialist and political theorist. In her early years, she studied philosophy and economics in university while learning Marxism. With others, Luxemburg founded the socialist Spartacus League in 1915 that would merge into the Communist Party. Alongside Karl Liebknecht, she co-founded the German Communist Party in 1918. When war broke out Luxemburg argued against any peace agreements that would preserve capitalist property relations. She was arrested and imprisoned until released at the end of the war. Luxemburg, a pacifist, opposed a socialist dictatorship and fought for universal suffrage. She was targeted by the Spartacist League and killed in 1919.

Along with songs like "Easy Skanking" and "Simmer Down," he's popularly known for songs like "No Woman, No Cry," "Buffalo Soldiér," and "I Shot the Sheriff." Marley's songs explored themes like love, warfare, poverty, racism, and religious beliefs. He passed away in 1981 at the age of 36.

input: Write a short biography of Bob Marley.
output: Bob Marley (1945-1981) was a singer and songwriter of reggae music and cultural icon of popular music. He played an influential role in the Rastafarian movement and his distinct vocal style earned him the nickname "the voice of reggae." Marley was discovered in Jamaica by guitarist Peter Tosh, who introduced him to Island Records executive Chris Blackwell. Marley released his first international record "Stir It Up" in 1972 and quickly became a chart-topping success. He embraced political and social activism and, with the Wailers, helped broaden reggae's appeal to mainstream audiences in the UK and US. Marley died of cancer in 1981. After his death, his music became widely popular globally, and he remained an enduring cultural icon.

input: Write a short biography of Bob Marley.
output: Robert "Bob" Nesta Marley (1945-1981) was a Jamaican musician, singer, and songwriter, and a central figure in the history and culture of reggae. Born to a black father and a white mother, Marley faced prejudice in a deeply segregated Jamaica. Marley learned to play the guitar and piano while working on a plantation. He founded the band the Wailers in 1963, recording their first hit "Small Axe" in 1964. Marley's hits include "One Love," "No Woman No Cry," and "Three Little Birds." Marley died in 1981 of brain cancer. In his obituary, Time Magazine chose him as "The First Black Hero of Postwar America."

input: Write a short biography of Bob Marley.
output: Robert Nesta "Bob" Marley (1945-1981) was a Jamaican reggae singer and songwriter who popularized the genre. Born to poor farming parents in Kingston, Marley began singing with friends and recorded his first single on an acetate record. The Wailers was formed in 1973 with Peter Tosh and Bunny Wailer and released the legendary "Rasta Revolution" album. Marley's second solo album, titled "Catch a Fire," became world famous, kickstarting his global fame. In the '70s, Marley's music criticized the harsh social conditions of Jamaica including poverty and racial tensions. Marley died of cancer in April 1981, but his legacy continues to inspire social justice movements around the world.

input: Write a short biography of Bob Marley.
output: Robert Nesta Marley (1945-1981) was a Jamaican singer and songwriter, the central figure of the reggae music movement. Marley was noted for his spiritual lyrics, and political and social activism, having released over 600 songs during his career. He began performing in local clubs as a teenager, and recorded his first album at age 19. His international breakthrough came with 1977's Exodus, which was a commercial success in the United States. Marley would continue recording until his death in 1981 from a malignant melanoma. His album Legend topped the charts in 1984, and Marley's legend has remained vibrant and relevant over the decades.

In 1982, Marley released an album of newly written material, _Confrontation_, which included the single "Buffalo Soldier," a UK top 40 hit. input: Write a short biography of Bob Marley.
output: Bob Marley (1945-1981) was an influential reggae singer. Raised in Nine Mile, Jamaica, Marley formed Bob Marley and the Wailers in 1963, and they released the album "Catch a Fire" in 1973. The group's albums "Rastaman Vibration" and "Exodus" reached number one in the UK in 1975 and 1977, respectively. Marley died in 1981 of cancer at age 36. He was posthumously awarded a Grammy Lifetime Award in 2012. Bob Marley is one of the most influential reggae musicians in history.
